body: Looks good to me. What's the impact on the documentation?
Please do not merge this just yet. I forgot to add the error messages to the Messages Manual. Will submit a rework shortly.

@zellerh , @DaveBirdsall , I leave the original checking below my change since as I googled, the definition of LLONG_MIN is 'undefined', different platform/libc and C and C++ compilers all may have different definition. But there are two basic choices:
LLONG_MIN as -9223372036854775808
or
LLONG_MIN as -9223372036854775807

So I was hoping in a system which defines the LLONG_MIN as 0x800000000000L or (-LLONG_MAX - 1 ) the first check that I modified will take effect and make sure -9223372036854775808 will be regarded as a valid number: 

For some older platform/compiler, the LLONG_MIN will be defined as -LLONG_MAX.  In this case, -9223372036854775808 should be regarded as invalid. The second check at line 2113 should take effect.

But I agree with you, line 2113 seems dangerous, and may not work as expected, but we cannot test it without using different platform/compiler/libc to figure out. And I think supporting older platform is not something valuable. Most mainstream systems use first LLONG_MIN definition (C++ 11 and later will use first def as well). So we are good to remove line 2113. I will remove those code and add comments to link to this RP discussion.

I refer to these:
http://howtoprogram.eu/question/integer-c-what-are-c-standard-guarantees-on-relation-between-min-and-max-values-of-signed-integer-types,12603
http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/climits/
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18687614/c-why-does-llong-min-llong-min
will update documentation as part of a separate task.

Extra Test failed at Known cases: Hive/TEST003, and compGeneral/TEST042,
This is for executor/TEST022. So this does not cause new failure and should be ready for merge.

And this change will not hide the root cause of TEST022 failure, but avoid it from fail, and this is a required change for Trafodion. I will continue to check why create table will sometimes need to convert -9223372036854775808, sometimes not. This can be done via a bugcatcher in ConvDoIt.

I'm opposed to adding the current proposal to Trafodion, here are my reasons:
- Right now there is not a 1:1 relationship between a UDR object and an invocation of a TMUDF. Therefore we cannot store data that is related to an invocation in the UDR object. It would be good to have a discussion on this design question.
- The emitRow method doesn't have access to the result columns, and it is not possible to handle things like passthrough columns. This method should have an "info" and a "plan" parameter, also maybe a way to pass only some of the result columns.
- We should try to support multiple input tables in new code we are adding.
- The proposed interface works only for mappers, not for reducers (it does not detect partition boundaries). Also note that I would like to add a new interface that makes writing reducers easier, by having a method to read the next row within a partition. See [TRAFODION-1129](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TRAFODION-1129).
- I'm sure other people will have different views on what a more convenient TMUDF interface will look like. Should we allow them to add their favorite interface as well? How many interfaces should we allow? For that reason I have a preference to keeping a single interface.

Again, adding it to the [code examples](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/TRAFODION/Trafodion+Code+Examples) would be very good and useful. I could also imagine adding the emitRow method that is proposed here to the Trafodion interface, after comments are addressed.

@sureshsubbiah, I'm wondering what you think.
TRAFODION-2231 is created to track error string apart from error code.
Is this code ready to commit?

I am working on an update for this.  Should deliver this change shortly.


Thank you @mashengchen for this code. I do not fully understand the need for this interface and exactly how it will be used. Do you think it will be better if file a JIRA explaining the purpose and providing examples (with a SQL query, and all java listings and example output).

I do get that the motivation for SimpleUDR is to provide a less complex interface when a TMUDF writer wants to acheive simpler tasks. But how this new interface does that, without sacrificing performance is not clear to me. In addition there are the issue @zellerh raised about having a unified interface and having some of the original principles in mind when new extensions are proposed.

In summary as @zeller suggested I see two alternatives
1) We add this change to code examples, to be used by those already comfortable with it
2) OR, we file a JIRA with the objective behind this change and then discuss this further there.

In the current interface other than processData all methods are optional, so I don't quite get how simplicity can be achieved. Maybe the goal is not simplicity after all, but an alternate JDBC type interface with prepare/execute/close?  

Please don't take these comments to indicate a lack of interest in this change.  However, as it stands it is likely not ready for mainline. New interfaces for TMUDF (and new uses for the existing interfaces) are always fascinating. @DaveBirdsall had suggested recently how it would be nice to support Java UDFs that are part of other Apache projects like HiveMall. So this an exciting and wide ranging area. Hope we can discuss this some more.

@zellerh about your point 1,is that means its thread-unsafe in UDR? The UDR always be a single instance? If so I have to change UDRInvocationInfo as param to execute(), but it seems not elegance. Or is there any suggestion?

@zellerh @sureshsubbiah  SimpleUDR is not trying to replace original UDR. It's true that if the users want to use original UDR, they can go ahead. SimpleUDR is to cover one of the scenarios and try to simplify the implementation. True, if SimpleUDR does not meet your requirements, please extend UDR directly. Again, SimpleUDR exists for special usage and it does not impact any current functions or performance. It's like that in JAVA it has InputStream, why it needs FileInputStream, ByteArrayInputStream, BufferedInputStream and so on? I think you might know what we're doing. Yes for special usage.
something wrong, I will abandon this PR.

@mashengchen, it's not so much about thread safety as about multiple invocations of a UDR. Here is an example:

`select * from udf(myudf()) u1, udf(myudf()) u2`

UDFs U1 and U2 will have two different UDRInvocationInfo objects, but they may share the same UDR object. Your code is not designed to handle that.

Note that I said "may", since this behavior is something we could change, but right now this is how it is defined.
This change has a severe issue, so will abandon and resubmit with a new PR.
pyodbc test failed, not related to this change, retest
Previous Test Aborted. New Check Test Started: https://jenkins.esgyn.com/job/Check-PR-master/1164/

yes, in phase 2, the default will be turned on. It is discussed as part of jira 2234

attribute could be specified explicitly during ddl or based the default value of the cqd.
Once specified, it becomes part of table attribute irrespective of what the default value
is when the table is used or showddl is issued.

Currently, showddl shows aligned attribute explicitly and nothing for hbase attribute.
So if nothing is displayed, then the table has hbase attr.

What we can do is to show explicit attribute for both hbase and aligned format.
This will be similar to how serialization property of a column is explicitly displayed
irrespective of how it was declared (explicitly or through a cqd default value).
That way if showddl will correctly represent how a table was originally created.

We can make that change for phase e.

to a conclusion regarding it?
